bboxes.raw_text:
The speech therapy department
of Gompers Memorial Rehabili-
ration Center is the training
ground for university students
this summer.


Two students are working go
hours each at Compers in clint
cal practicum speech therapy,
under the direct supervision of
DR.. Elizabeth Van Auven, direc-
tor of speech and hearing. The
work serves as an intership in
speech therapy. as 200 hours of
clinical practicum are required
in order to practice profession
ally.


Students are Mrs. Claire Roth
stein. who received her BIS degree
in speech pathology from the Uni
versity of Minnesot and is work
ing on her MS degree through the
University of Arizona: and Miss
Stephanie Greenhouse, formerly
at the University of Arizona, will
be a senior at A .S.U.


The center has 100 patients in
speech therapy this summer, and
is evaluating about 10 new people
weekly.

Compers Center
Aids University


Students Work

WASHINGTON. DC. Pres.
Johnson was told by DR.. Fred
erick D. Patterson. president of
the United Negro College Fund,
that "as barriers to equal oppor-
tunity continue to fall, more young
people, saved from deprivation,
indignity and despair, will be able
to go on to higher education and
prepare themselves for the
greater opportunities which will
surely come


DR.. Patterson, who founded the
Fund, Americas first educa-
tional community chest, in 1914;
met with President Johnson to
report on the first phase of the
Emancipation Centennial Cam
paign for $5O.oOO,0OO launched
by the late President Kennedy
on September IL, 1868. DR.. Pat
terson said that S33 100000 had
been raised in cash and pledges
to date.

The New Zion Baptist Church,
New Orleans, can be called the
home of the Southern Christian
Leadership Conference. The ini-
tial meeting of SCLC had


occurred in Atlanta Jan. lO-1l,


1857 under the leadership of DR..
Martin Luther King, Jr., of Mont
gomery: the Rev. Fred L. Shut
Ellsworth of Birmingham: the
Rev. C. K. Steele, of Tallahassee
and the Rev. T. ]. Jemison of
Baton Rouge, La. About 90 per-
sons from % communities in 10
different states appeared. The
idea born in New Orleans mater
ialized in the first meeting at
Ebenezer Baptist Church in At
lanta.


Bayard Rustin attended and
plans were drawn to fight bus
jim crow. DR.. King was forced
to leave the meetings when bombs
we're thrown in Montgomery. His
wife, Coretta is credited with
helping to hold the interest high
and the formation of SCLC was
successfully made.


DR.. Martin L. King, Jr., was
elected president. He wrote in
letter from an Atlanta jail on
April IL, 1868; eve have waited
for more than $40 years for our
constitutional and God-given
rights. The nations of Asia and
Africa are moving with jetlike
speed toward the goal of political
independence, and we still creep
at horse and buggy pace toward
the gaining of a cup of coffee at
a lunch counter We will win
our freedom because the sacred
heritage of our nation and the
will of God are embodied
IN our echoing demands"

BY FLORA RUFFIN


MIR. and Mrs. Leon Kidd of
Gary. Ind. are houseguests Of
the Roosevelt Sims.


Marlene Chambers has re-
turned from Los Angeles visit.


A closing fiscal year dinner
was held last Sunday at the Tay-
lor Memorial Interracial Spiri-
tual Church, l245 w. Watkins.
Rev. John Meeker was guest
speaker. His message was en-
titled, "Moses the Leader"


Mrs. H. Waggoner won the sun
flower growing contest. Mem
bers had planted seeds in Feb
rurary. Hers was 2 #. IA ms.


The delayed visit of the year
was made when Mrs. Ethel East
man was reunited with her niece,
Mrs. Fred (Florine) Oliver after
more than 20 years. She spent
several days with MIR. and Mrs.
Fred Oliver, returning this week
to San Jose, Calf, due to her
husbands Illness.


Mr.. and Mrs. Walter Brown,
1920 S. FL ST., hosted lookout
for MIR. and Mrs. Fred Waters
and Mrs. Virginia Scott. of Los
Angeles. Other guests we're Hay
wood Hundy Of San Diego, MIR. and
Mrs. William Hooks of Phoenix
and Floyd Hooks of Kokomo, Ind.

MEDFORD. Mass. A party
ended in a race riot when several
hundred white and Negro teen
ayers fought. The trouble started
after Negro tried to skate with
a white girl.


About ten persons we're In
jured. There we're no arrests.
A police car was overturned and
chartered bus was badly
damaged.

Roy Wilkins is Executive Sec
rotary of the National ASS ociation
for the Advancement of Colored
People, was unanimously named
by the board of directors on April
IL, 1855, to succeed Walter White
who died on March 81. He lives
in New York City where the Asso-
citation has its national headquar-
tiers at 20 West 10th Street, New
York, N. Y. lOOl8.


He joined the staff of the
NAACP in 1881 as Assistant
Executive Secretary and while
filling that position was also
Q934-49) Editor of The Crisis,
the monthly magazine that is the
official organ Of the NAACP. Mr..
Wilkins was Acting Secretary of
the NAACP from June l. lo49,
to May 81. 1850. during Walter
Whites leave of absence. From
1850 to his election as Executive
Secretary, Mr.. Wilkins served as
Administrator.


He was born in St. Louis, Mis-
souri,, but grew up in St. Paul.
MINES ota, where he finished the
public schools and was graduated
from the University of Minnesota.
For eight years he worked on the
staff of The Kansas City Call, a
weekly newspaper in Kansas City,
Missouri.


The NAACP has had an inter-
racial membership and corps Of
directors and officers since its
founding in 1909. The 1868 paid
membership was SIS. 900. located
in 1858 branches and youth
groups in 40 states and the Dis
trict of Columbia.
